repnme.cdata!:
Across Indonesia, villagers invest in own
            infrastructure needs

abstracts.cdata!:
The Kecamatan (Sub-district) Development
            Program (KDP) was initiated as a pilot in 1998 in 28
            villages in Indonesia at a time of great political and
            financial upheaval. With poverty rising to 23 percent and
            institutions of government weakening with Suharto's
            exit, conventional top-down approaches to development did
            not offer the most effective way to address the needs of the
            rural poor. Further, challenges posed by widespread
            corruption and cronyism were hampering delivery of
            development projects and created the need for an innovative
            method that was transparent in providing project funds
            directly to villagers. Later in 2001, when Indonesia
            decentralized its governance structure, the KDP provided
            support in building local level capacity for governance
            through its large network of facilitators.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Village Infrastructure
            Project and Kecamatan Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Village Infrastructure
            Project had a satisfactory outcome and had a substantial
            institutional development impact, although its
            sustainability cannot be evaluated. The performances of both
            the Bank and the Borrower were satisfactory. The Kecamatan
            Development Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome
            with substantial institutional development impact although
            it too has a sustainability that cannot be evaluated. Here
            also the performances of both the Bank and the Borrower were
            satisfactory. Six lessons were suggested by these two
            projects: 1) Translate the project's poverty objectives
            into clearly defined outcomes and outputs in the Project
            Appraisal Document that can be monitored and evaluated. 2)
            Project management has to intervene at the community to
            support poverty and gender issues and challenge the status.
            3) Develop an infrastructure maintenance strategy that
            addresses the total community infrastructure. 4) Reduce the
            costs -including time spent in meetings -- of beneficiary
            participation as the number of program's increases. 5)
            Heed past lessons in rural finance: Effective and
            sustainable rural finance calls for an institutional
            capacity to evaluate debt capacity, a sustainable
            institutional home, low costs, and strong incentives for the
            borrower(s) to remain in good standing. In the Kecamatan
            project it was a mistake to force an economic loans
            component into a grants program outside a carefully prepared
            rural finance intervention. 6) Define at the outset some
            kind of baseline (and related milestones) regarding the
            level of corruption, so as to measure progress.

repnme.cdata!:
Economic impact analysis of Kecamatan
            Development Program infrastructure projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Indonesia and the
            World Bank commissioned this independent study to conduct a
            post-construction economic impact analysis on 113 Kecamatan
            Development Program (KDP) rural infrastructure projects to
            determine the overall economic benefits that have accrued to
            the villages that planned and built infrastructure
            facilities according to the KDP Community Driven Development
            approach. This study expands on the scale and scope of the
            initial economic analysis that was completed for 41 KDP
            projects in November 2001 under KDP 1. That study was
            limited to calculating Economic Internal Rates of Return
            only. In contrast, this study focuses on three main
            activities: (1) Assessing tangible benefits by calculating
            the Economic Internal Rates of Return for the four types of
            KDP rural infrastructure; (2) Analysing the overall
            macro-economic impact of new income generated by KDP
            infrastructure activities within the local village economies
            by using (i) a General Income Multiplier Analysis and (ii)
            Project-Specific Quality of Life Indicators to capture
            certain intangible benefits that have accrued since the
            projects completion; and (3) Undertake a Least-Cost
            Analysis by re-costing KDP infrastructure projects using
            local contractor rates to determine what the same project
            would cost if tendered out by local government to local contractors.

            INDONESIA LOCAL LEVEL INSTITUTION,TF036613-EAST ASIA - SOCIAL POLICY IN
            DEVELOPMENT COUNTRIES,BBNSA2-BB NEW SPENDING AUTHORITY 2,TF020611-ASEM - INDONESIA-STRUCTURAL
            REFORMS & DEREGULATION PROGRAM,TF037881-INDONESIA - POVERTY MONITORING,TF025518-PHRD-KECAMATAN DEVELOPMENT FUND PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated highly
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts are high. Many useful lessons for
            community-driven development projects are drawn from this
            project. Human resource development, and capacity building
            are good investments, and critical to program success.
            Training was especially important since the project was
            introducing principles, and procedures (i.e., participation,
            transparency, accountability, etc.) that represented a
            radical departure from the practices built up under years of
            authoritarian rule, in a centralized top-down planning.
            Nevertheless, the project fell short in addressing
            effectively a number of training competences, and in
            addressing such training through a sustained strategy for
            developing capacities continuously, and transferring skills
            gradually. Similarly, technical assistance (TA), and
            supervision for village infrastructure projects in
            particular need to be strengthened. Furthermore, communities
            also require more quality training in the areas of planning,
            financial management, and construction skills. Another
            important lesson is that community participation can improve
            through better facilitation, communications, and outreach,
            while poverty targeting within villages was weak, which led
            to the exclusion of some of the more marginal and poorer
            segments of the population. Other lessons address the need
            to increase women's participation; to continue support
            for an independent civil society monitoring, as well as
            invest in strong monitoring, evaluations, and studies; to
            facilitate the redesign of the economic loan portfolio,
            given the difficulties experienced in managing the
            micro-credit component; and, to establish mechanisms to
            reduce corruption.

2419560.trustfund:
TF020611-ASEM - INDONESIA-STRUCTURAL
            REFORMS & DEREGULATION PROGRAM,TF025518-PHRD-KECAMATAN DEVELOPMENT FUND PROJECT,TF036613-EAST ASIA - SOCIAL POLICY IN
            DEVELOPMENT COUNTRIES,TF037881-INDONESIA - POVERTY MONITORING

abstracts.cdata!:
The World Bank aided Kecamatan
            Development Project (KDP) is a community-based project,
            initiated by the Government of Indonesia, to alleviate rural
            poverty levels. The distinctive feature of the project is
            its highly decentralized nature, which devolves
            decision-making down to the villagers themselves. A
            kecamatan, or council, is an administrative unit made up of
            multiple villages. Villagers are empowered to exercise full
            control over their developmental decisions from
            identification of their needs to implementation of the
            project. The project also focuses on gender equality and
            encourages women to participate in planning and
            decision-making activities. The first phase of the project
            was completed by the Government of Indonesia in September
            2002. Infrastructure projects for roads, bridges, water
            supply systems, and school repairs were executed in more
            than 21,000 villages in about 1,000 kecamatans throughout
            the country. The Indonesian Department of Home Affairs is
            currently in charge of the implementation of the next phase,
            KDP-II. However, high levels of corruption have been
            reported in relation to the release of funds and the
            procurement of materials. With loan repayment rates as low
            as 50-60 percent, the financial sustainability of the
            project also remains an issue to be addressed. In addition,
            the project requires a more responsive technical support
            structure if the objectives set forth in terms of
            procurement, financial management, and project quality are
            to be achieved.

repnme.cdata!: Giving villagers a voice in Indonesia

abstracts.cdata!:
In villages across the Indonesian
            archipelago, similar projects are being developed under the
            World Bank-funded Kecamatan development project (KDP), a
            community-empowerment initiative. Villagers living in
            Kecamatans, or sub-districts, receive grants for projects
            they themselves choose. According to one Sulawesi
            women's group, KDP has had significant liberating
            effects for women, whose time and effort have been freed up
            by many of the village projects. Over the past four years,
            the project has built roads stretching over 19,000
            kilometers, and erected or rehabilitated some 3,500 bridges.
            It has constructed 5,200 irrigation systems to improve crop
            yields, and has supplied 2,800 communities with clean
            drinking water.

repnme.cdata!: Giving villagers a voice in Indonesia

abstracts.cdata!:
In villages across the Indonesian
            archipelago, similar projects are being developed under the
            World Bank-funded Kecamatan development project (KDP), a
            community-empowerment initiative. Villagers living in
            Kecamatans, or sub-districts, receive grants for projects
            they themselves choose. According to one Sulawesi
            women's group, KDP has had significant liberating
            effects for women, whose time and effort have been freed up
            by many of the village projects. Over the past four years,
            the project has built roads stretching over 19,000
            kilometers, and erected or rehabilitated some 3,500 bridges.
            It has constructed 5,200 irrigation systems to improve crop
            yields, and has supplied 2,800 communities with clean
            drinking water.

docna.cdata!: Les villageois ont la parole, en Indonésie

Giving villagers a voice in
            Indonesia : Les villageois ont la parole, en Indonésie
